title: Linux Performance Analysis in 60 Seconds
summary: Netflix engineer Brendan Gregg published a practical guide on quickly diagnosing Linux system performance issues using standard command-line tools (top, vmstat, iostat, netstat, dmesg, pidstat). The 82-comment discussion showcased a strong developer community sharing additional tools (htop, glances, atop, iotop, iftop), discussing their trade-offs, and celebrating how this knowledge is now widely accessible rather than being a premium consulting skill. Key themes included automation of performance analysis, tool recommendations, and exploring deeper analysis methods like the USE method. The article generated significant appreciation from the community for making performance troubleshooting knowledge accessible.
what_happened: Over the past 10 years (2015-2025), Linux performance analysis has fundamentally evolved. The traditional tools discussed (top, iostat, vmstat, perf) remain widely used and relevant, demonstrating the durability of the article's advice. However, eBPF (extended Berkeley Packet Filter) emerged as a transformative technology, enabling kernel-space observability without the overhead of traditional user-space monitoring tools. eBPF-based tools now provide insights that traditional monitoring couldn't deliver, with capabilities like automatic instrumentation, zero-copy kernel access, and minimal performance overhead. The eBPF ecosystem matured significantly in 2024-2025 with the formation of the eBPF Foundation by major tech companies. Systemd became dominant for log management, replacing traditional text-based syslog on most distributions. Modern observability evolved toward distributed tracing and service mesh monitoring for cloud-native environments. Brendan Gregg himself left Netflix in 2022 to become an Intel Fellow, now focusing on AI performance and pioneering eBPF observability. The fundamental troubleshooting methodology (CPU → memory → disk → network) remains timeless, but the tooling and deeper analysis methods have expanded significantly. Linux kernel observability capabilities improved with BTF (BPF Type Format) and CO-RE (Compile Once - Run Everywhere), making advanced tracing more portable and practical.

most_prescient.reason: As the article author himself, Brendangregg's comment about trimmed-out follow-on tools (perf record with flamegraphs, execsnoop, turbostat, slabtop, iosnoop, iotop, netstat, tcpdump, tcpretrans) proved prescient. He noted these tools existed but were omitted for brevity. A decade later, these advanced tools (especially flamegraphs and perf-based analysis) became standard practice. More importantly, his perf-tools project and later pioneering of eBPF observability represents the exact direction the field moved—from the basic 60-second tools toward sophisticated kernel-space tracing and visualization, ultimately vindicating his vision of deeper performance analysis being essential.

most_wrong.reason: Jandrese expressed disappointment that the article didn't drill down into solving the actual problem shown in the example and suggested that 'none of it had any visibility inside of their Java VM.' While understandable at the time, this missed the forest for the trees. The article was intentionally about methodology and quick triage, not deep application-level debugging. More importantly, the comment underestimated how powerful external OS-level observability could be. In the subsequent decade, the field proved that kernel-space observability (especially through eBPF) became MORE powerful and comprehensive than application-level introspection alone. Modern eBPF tools now trace Java VMs and provide insights that bytecode-level instrumentation struggles to deliver, ultimately vindicating the OS-level observability approach.

notable_aspects: 1) The nostalgic anecdote from luckydude about commanding $8,000/day for Linux performance consulting during the dot-com era, then seeing this knowledge democratized and routinely available—perfectly captures how knowledge commoditization benefits the industry overall. 2) Multiple commenters suggested automation/solutions (Conky, monit, glances, Splunk, collectd+Graphite), yet a decade later the trend hasn't been toward fully automated diagnosis but rather toward better visibility tools, confirming that humans still need to understand what they're looking at. 3) The Netflix blog redesign issues discussed in comments (broken links, missing RSS) foreshadowed the ongoing problem of link rot and outdated web infrastructure at major companies. 4) Discussion of virtualization overhead (systemd, steal time, Xen credit scheduler) is less prominent today but remains relevant in containerized environments. 5) The article appeared just before containers/Kubernetes mainstream adoption, so all discussion assumes single-system analysis rather than distributed system observability.

brendangregg.rationale: The author provided timeless foundational methodology that remains relevant a decade later. The 60-second framework is still taught and used. His follow-up tools comment and career trajectory (leaving Netflix to pioneer eBPF) shows he understood where observability was headed and helped build it.

anarcat.rationale: Provided substantive tool recommendations (iftop, tcpdump, systemd/journalctl) that have stood the test of time. All tools mentioned are still widely used and relevant in 2025. Demonstrated deep practical knowledge.

luckydude.rationale: Insightful historical perspective showing this knowledge has been valuable for decades and validating the article's approach. Accurately predicted commoditization of expertise. No technical errors, mostly observational wisdom.

jandrese.rationale: Missed the point of methodology-focused content, expected a solved case study instead. The criticism about Java VM visibility was ultimately wrong—eBPF now provides kernel-space insights into Java that application-level monitoring alone cannot match. Underestimated OS-level observability potential.

ipozgaj.rationale: Made valid technical point that top/htop miss short-lived processes, correctly recommending atop as solution. This observation remains true in 2025. Minor point: could have mentioned perf's capabilities for this same use case.

baldfat.rationale: Strong endorsement of dmesg and atop, both still relevant tools. The enthusiasm is warranted. dmesg improvements over the decade (better timestamps, human-readable output) have made the tool even more useful than in 2015.

cthalupa.rationale: Made technical correction about Xen credit scheduler behavior and steal time, showing nuanced understanding of virtualization. This level of detail remains accurate but is less commonly needed in modern cloud-native deployments.

samstave.rationale: Valid question about Windows equivalents and disk I/O measurement. The response mentioning xperf/wpr was accurate. Question was practical but outside the article's scope, so less prescient about industry trends.

Aissen.rationale: Asked important question about automating performance analysis. The suggestions (Conky, monit, glances, collectd) were good but the question itself proved less important than expected—industry didn't move toward full automation but rather better visualization/accessibility tools.

jerf.rationale: Asked about memory bandwidth analysis, an edge case. The responses mentioning PMCs/perf counters were correct but this use case has remained niche. Modern tools like eBPF made this somewhat easier but it's still not mainstream.
